results.title: Anzac: a nation's heritage
results.brief_description: The ANZAC performance at Gallipoli is examined as are the towns that are there today and the graves that remain. Likens the ANZACS to the Greek heroes of ancient times. This is an edited version of a commemorative film made in 1965, 50 years after the landing of Australian and New Zealand troops at Gallipoli on April 25th, 1915. Highlights include memorial services in Australia, New Zealand and Britain, a re-enactment at Anzac Cove and scenes of Gallipoli and Troy today.

results.title: Anywhere Out of the World
results.brief_description: ‘Anywhere Out of the World’ (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks.

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

results.description: Anywhere Out of the World (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks. In 1999 Parreno and Huyghe bought the rights to a Japanese manga character they named “Annlee”. They lifted all copyrights from the character, asking other artists and designers to create various artworks with Annlee as a protagonist. Parreno’s film is the first episode in this series of projects, and is characterized by a unique sequence in which Annlee presents herself as a girl without a past, and declares her existence as a product free of any copyright or market restrictions. Annlee’s voice was created digitally by the artist. Her presence has an ambiguous quality: she is a melancholy character, devoid of quality, deigned to remain a simulated reality. In addition to dealing with themes of copyright and authorship, the artwork reflects on the ways and circumstances that lead to the definition of an identity in the contemporary era.
description_for_label: Anywhere Out of the World (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks. They lifted all copyrights from the character, asking other artists and designers to create various artworks with Annlee as a protagonist. Parreno’s film is the first episode in this series of projects, and is characterized by a unique sequence in which Annlee presents herself as a girl without a past, and declares her existence as a product free of any copyright or market restrictions. Annlee’s voice was created digitally by the artist. Her presence has an ambiguous quality: she is a melancholy character, devoid of quality, deigned to remain a simulated reality. results.title: Antony and Cleopatra (Perspective)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Shakespeare in Perspective Series”.
Designed to give a greater understanding and appreciation of the play by placing it in its social and historical context and by stressing its relevance for a modern-day audience. Perspective offered by Anna Raeburn, journalist and television personality.

results.title: Antonio Gaudi: to a dancing god
results.brief_description: Filmed in Barcelona, this program is an examination of the Art Nouveau architecture and philosophy of Spanish architect, Antonio Gaudi. It takes a retrospective look at his work, exploring the strong, sure buildings, churches and mosaics that were his masterpiece. This film was submitted by Theo Mathews as his thesis for an Associateship in Architecture at the Western Australian Institute of Technology. Suitable for Middle-Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Antonio Gaudi
results.creator_credit: Centre for Mass Communication, Columbia University
results.brief_description: Explores the work of one of architecture’s greatest innovators. Using Gaudi’s credo “originality is a return to the origin” as a guideline, shows how the architect’s highly personal sense of space evolved from the Mediterranean forms he knew so well. Starting with the Casa Vicens (1878) we follow the major developments in his career. In each building Gaudi’s flamboyant use of colour and unusual structural devices are fully discussed.

results.title: Anthropology and the future
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In this last program of the series, anthropologist and producer of the series Ira R. Abrams, leads a discussion with two other anthropologists, Napoleon A. Chagnon and Laura Nader on the future of anthropology. Is the subject matter of anthropology disappearing or simply changing? What are the ethical consequences of the anthropologist’s work? Where does the future of anthropology lie? The ideas discussed are various and fascinating, and in the light of recent developments in world power structures, and in the Amazonian jungles, timely and thought provoking too.

results.title: Antarctica
results.creator_credit: Bastian Wimmer, Clayton J. Edwards and Image Associates
results.brief_description: Examines some of the significant research projects being carried out in Antartica under the auspices of the National Science Foundation. Shows how these projects relate to worldwide concerns and emphasizes the cooperation of American scientists with those from other countries.

results.title: Antarctic man. No. 2. This is not a place for humans
results.creator_credit: David Parer and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: This is the second part of a two-part documentary recording the International Biomedical Expedition to the Antarctic. The purpose of the expedition was to measure the effects of the Antarctic environment on both the human body and mind, including the extreme cold climate, isolation and separation from family and home. Shows the physiological and psychological pressures and physical limits the Expedition set for themselves. Some coped, some didn’t - but the ordeal had a lasting effect on all of them. Narrated by W. Francis Bell.
